Exercise 3.1-7

Prove that the running time of an algorithm is if and only if its worst-case running time is and its best-case running time is .

Mathematically proving this boils down to the same work done in Exercise 3.1-5 since this statement also relies on Theorem 3.1. What follows is an informal explanation of why this statement is true.

Suppose and that and indicate the worst-case and best-case runtimes of respectively. Based on Thereom 3.1 we know that and .

Saying has an upper-bound represented by is the same as saying that in the worst-case, will not exceed . This indicates that . Similar logic can be used to describe that .

The key here is that is the set of all functions that include and lie between and . The usage of , and -notation is a mathematically rigorous way of describing the area this set of functions is bound by with the worst-case run time defining the upper-bound and the best-case run time defining the lower bound.

If we suppose instead that and that, say, then we are saying that exceeds the upper-bound represented by which in turn implies that also exceeds the upper-bound represented by since a possible run-time of . This is clearly a contradiction, and the same argument applies to making the claim that .
